description: From Middle English sugre candy, from Old French sucre candi (literally “candied sugar”), from Arabic سُكَّر قَنْدِي‎ (sukkar qandī), from Arabic قَنْد‎ (qand, “rock candy”), from Persian کند‎ (kand); likely from Sanskrit खण्ड (khaṇḍa, “piece, fragment, candied sugar, dried molasses”), root खण्ड् (khaṇḍ, “to divide, break into pieces”), or from Proto-Dravidian *kaṇṭu; compare Tamil கண்டு (kaṇṭu, “hard candy”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable, chiefly Canada, US, Philippines) Edible, sweet-tasting confectionery containing sugar, or sometimes artificial sweeteners, and often flavored with fruit, chocolate, nuts, herbs and spices, or artificial flavors.
(countable, chiefly Canada, US, Philippines) A piece of confectionery of this kind.
(uncountable) An accessory (bracelet, etc.) made from pony beads, associated with the rave scene.

verbs.description: candy (third-person singular simple present candies, present participle candying, simple past and past participle candied)

entries.meaning: (cooking) To cook in, or coat with, sugar syrup.
(intransitive) To have sugar crystals form in or on.
examples: Fruits preserved in sugar candy after a time.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be formed into candy; to solidify in a candylike form or mass.

description: From Marathi खंडी (khaṇḍī), from Sanskrit खण्डन (khaṇḍana), from root खण्ड् (khaṇḍ, “to divide, break into pieces”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A unit of mass used in southern India, equal to twenty maunds, roughly equal to 500 pounds avoirdupois but varying locally.
